text: you know spiders have problems too like
this really creepy maggot like wasp
larvae it grows on a spiders back and
makes it change its web to make a home
for the larvas cocoon how Japanese
scientists think the larvae uses a
chemical signal to co-opt one of the
spiders natural behaviors these
orb-weaver spiders make a sticky web
like this to catch prey they also make
resting webs like this when they're
about to molt the larva tells the spider
take apart this sticky web build a
resting web that web has few spokes and
fibrous threads that reflect ultraviolet
light that could warn off birds and big
insects that could fly into the web and
destroy it then the larva gobbles up the
spider and uses the web as a home for
its own cocoon kind of makes you feel
bad for the spider or does it
